repnme.cdata!: Cape Verde - Social Sector Development Project

abstracts.cdata!:
The outcome for the Social Sector
            Development Project for Cape Verde was satisfactory, the
            sustainability was likely, the institutional development
            impact was substantial, and the Bank and borrower
            performance were both satisfactory. Lessons learned from the
            project: Aspects such as social capital development and
            capacity building should receive careful attention,
            especially with a decentralized approach. Key Performance
            Indicators (KPIs) should be carefully determined at project
            start and limited to those most relevant to the operation.
            Monitoring and evaluation tools should be simple and user
            friendly. Use of national competitive bidding procurement
            method instead of small works procurement method.

repnme.cdata!: Cape Verde - Social Sector Development Project

abstracts.cdata!:
The overall development objective of the
            Social Sector Development Project is to contribute to reduce
            poverty among the 30 percent of the population living below
            the poverty line. There are two project components. The
            first funds public works and employment creation by
            financing 1) equipment and operating costs for AGECABO (a
            delegated contract management agency); 2) economic and
            social infrastructures costing $20,000 and above; 3)
            training of contractors in the construction sector; 4)
            technical assistance for capacity building of municipalities
            to plan, implement, and monitor projects and account for
            resource use; 5) demand-driven small-scale social
            infrastructures which are implemented by communities; 6)
            training of communities, nongovernmental organizations, and
            municipalities in participatory approaches, micro-project
            preparation and management, and technical fields; 7)
            investment and recurrent costs of the community window in
            AGECABO. The second component, focusing on capacity building
            and monitoring and evaluation finances technical assistance
            to and training for the program coordination unit, equipment
            and limited operating costs, studies and surveys, and
            technical and financial audits.
